data.title: George Lucas, Herb Alpert win White House arts awards
data.meta_description: Star Wars director George Lucas and Tijuana Brass founder Herb Alpert are to be honoured with the National Medal of Arts at a White House ceremony next week.
data.text:
Star Wars filmmaker George Lucas and Tijuana Brass founder Herb Alpert will be honoured with the National Medal of Arts at a White House ceremony next week.

U.S. President Barack Obama named 12 winners of the National Medal of the Arts and another 12 winners of the National Humanities Medal ahead of the July 4 holiday in the U.S.

Among the Humanities Medal honourees is University of Toronto professor Natalie Zemon Davis, a noted social historian and author. Known for her exploration of social history, especially the lives of women, she penned the 1982 book The Return of Martin Guerre, which led to a feature film.

"With vivid description and exhaustive research, her works allow us to experience life through our ancestors' eyes and to engage truly with our history," says the White House citation in her honour.

Lucas, 69, created the Star Wars franchise and the Indiana Jones films, as well as TV spinoffs of both.

"By combining the art of storytelling with boundless imagination and cutting-edge techniques, Lucas has transported us to new worlds and created some of the most beloved and iconic films of all time," the White House said in its citation.

Alpert, who is being honoured for his contribution to music, was co-founder of A&M Records as well as the Tijuana Brass. He worked with artists such as The Carpenters, Sergio Mendes and Janet Jackson.

Also receiving the arts honour are Angels in America playwright and screenwriter Tony Kushner, opera singer Renée Fleming and screenwriter Elaine May. Other National Medal of the Arts winners:

Philanthropist Lin Arison.

Dancer and choreographer Joan Myers Brown.

Author and teacher Ernest Gaines.

Painter and sculptor Ellsworth Kelly.

Landscape architect Laurie Olin.

Musician and composer Allen Toussaint.

The Washington Performing Arts Society.

The recipients of the National Humanities Medal are:

Historian Edward L. Ayers.

Economist and education theorist William G. Bowen.

Historian and writer Jill Ker Conway (The Road from Coorain).

Sports writer Frank Deford of Sports Illustrated.

Author Joan Didion (The Year of Magical Thinking).

Political scientist Robert Putnam.

Author Marilynne Robinson (Gilead).

Poet Kay Ryan.

Robert B. Silvers., editor of the New York Review of Books.

Actress and playwright Anna Deavere Smith.

Writer and photographer Camilo José Vergara.

President Obama will present the medals next Wednesday at the White House in Washington, D.C.
